entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) Automated iFlow Comparison and Summarization Using Generative AI
entry.content:
When multiple teams collaborate on the same SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) iFlow, changes can pile up quickly and it becomes difficult to pinpoint what was altered, who changed it, and which modifications must be transported to higher environments. To solve this, I built sapci_iflow_compare, a lightweight Streamlit app that fetches two iFlow XMLs and generates a technical, element-level diff, with an optional AI summary to make the results easy to review.

This blog walks through what the tool does and how to run it. It also explains why not to upload iFlow XMLs directly to public chatbots and how this approach keeps your content safer.

What the Solution Does

  • Connects to CI/CPI design‑time via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts to retrieve the selected iFlow’s ZIP and extract the .iflw XML for comparison (or accepts two local .iflw files) 
  • Matches nodes by id and performs a recursive comparison (attributes, text, structure), ignoring order differences where relevant, to produce a precise, developer‑friendly diff.
  • Displays the raw technical diff and (optionally) sends only the minimized difference report to Gemini for a human‑readable summary; you can disable the AI step entirely for strict confidentiality.

Architecture Overview

  • Inputs

Two CI/CPI design‑time endpoints (OAuth client credentials), or two local .iflw XMLs

 

  • API & Extraction

Calls /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts on your tenant to fetch the artifact content (ZIP) and extract the .iflw XML. 

 

  • Diff Engine

Parses both XMLs and generates an element‑level diff with attribute and text changes. 

 

  • Optional AI Summary

Sends only the diff to Gemini for summarization, not the entire iFlow XML, keeping exposure to a minimum

Connectivity & Security: Fetching iFlow XMLs via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts

The tool connects to design‑time using the Integration Content OData API (OData V2), specifically the IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts resource exposed on SAP API Business Hub. This API supports downloading design‑time artifacts

Endpoint Pattern

  • Tenant base URL (design‑time):
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com
  • Resource path:
    /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Typical call:
    GET /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='<ArtifactId>',Version='<ArtifactVersion>')/$value
    (Exact resource and operations are documented in the API reference.) [api.sap.com]

Authentication

Use OAuth2 Client Credentials against your XSUAA token endpoint to obtain an access token, then call the API with that token. SAP’s help portal details roles and inbound HTTP client setup for Integration Content OData API access

Option A: Configure credentials in config_file.json

If your policy permits, store per‑environment client credentials in the app’s JSON:

{
    "api1": {
      "name": "Source iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://source-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://source-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "source-client-id",
      "client_secret": "source-client-secret"
    },
    "api2": {
      "name": "Target iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://target-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://target-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "target-client-id",
      "client_secret": "target-client-secret"
    },
    "gemini_api_url": "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent",
    "gemini_api_key": "your-gemini-api-key"
  }
This uses the design‑time OData endpoint documented by SAP and the standard client‑credentials grant for server‑to‑server integration.
 

Option B: Enter credentials at runtime in Streamlit

If storing secrets locally is a security concern, leave the client_id and client_secret blank in the config and enter them at runtime in the Streamlit UI. The app holds them in memory for the session and does not write them to disk. You’ll input:

  • Tenant API URL:
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Token URL: https://<your-xsuaa-domain>/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: entered interactively in the UI

This approach adheres to the principle of minimizing persistence of credentials while leveraging the same SAP OData API

Setup & Run

  • Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare.git
cd sapci_iflow_compare
  • Install dependencies
pip3 install streamlit lxml requests
  • Choose your credential mode

Option A: Fill config_file.json with client credentials per environment.

Option B: Leave secrets empty and enter them at runtime via UI (recommended if local storage of secrets is not permitted).
(Both use the same SAP design‑time API.)

  • Run the app
python3 -m streamlit run iflow_compare.py
  • Click Compare iFlows to fetch, extract, and compare the two iFlow XMLs. Review the Raw Technical Diff and, if enabled, the AI Summary

Testing

  • I will use the Visual Studio code to run the .py file

  • Run the command

  • Page is opened in the browser as below and for simplicity, I will use Option A, using Config file, provide the config file path and click on compare iFlows

  • You can see the detailed differences of iFlow_1 and iFlow_2. If needed, it can be downloaded for detailed analysis

  • If needed, raw differences can be sent to Google Gemini and get the summary in readable format

This is just an idea and both difference logic and prompt can be extended as per the requirement

Recommended Use Cases

  1. Pre‑transport gate check
    Run a compare just before transport and attach the diff to your change ticket which mirrors best practice in community tools that emphasize confirming intended changes prior to moving artifacts. 

  2. Detect drift across packages/tenants
    Particularly useful when DEV and TEST coexist on the same tenant and packages fall out of sync is an issue documented by practitioners.

  3. Git workflows & automation
    Combine with GitHub sync (e.g., FlashPipe) and run the compare in a CI job or GitHub Action to block unintended changes on a pull request

Security: Why You Should Not Upload Full iFlow XMLs to Public Chatbots

Uploading raw iFlow XMLs (which may include endpoints, headers, and process logic) to public chatbots is risky:

  • Data training & retention: Public chatbot plans may use prompts to improve models and retain conversations (~30 days) even when training is disabled, which can violate internal policies for confidential data. (Enterprise plans have stronger guarantees, but that requires organizational adoption.) 

  • Real‑world incidents: Multiple organizations have restricted public chatbots after employees accidentally pasted confidential source code or internal materials; these cases underscore the leakage risk even when intentions are benign. 

  • SAP’s own caution: CI/CPI warns that placing sensitive values in headers or properties risks accidental exposure. Sending entire iFlow models externally increases that exposure surface. 

  • Safer pattern: Do your local comparison and, if you use AI, submit only a redacted difference report (no full iFlow XML) to your AI service or disable AI entirely. That is exactly how sapci_iflow_compare is designed

Conclusion

sapci_iflow_compare provides a repeatable, secure, and developer‑friendly way to compare iFlow changes across environments without exposing full iFlow XMLs to public chatbots. Whether you are preparing a transport, auditing changes, or reviewing a pull request, the element‑level diff and optional readable summary help you move faster with confidence. As conveyed previously, this is an idea which can be extended as per your requirements.

  • GitHub: Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare

Please try it out, share feedback, and help improve the SAP integration ecosystem!

entry.title: Accelerate Your Lead-to-Cash Cycle: Seamless SAP CPQ Quoting from SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
In the competitive world of Lead-to-Cash, a streamlined workflow for managing quotes is no longer a luxury—it's the foundation for sales teams to hit their targets faster. When speed and accuracy matter, moving from Opportunity to Quote should be instantaneous. With the use of out of box integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, sales team can now initiate quote creation without ever leaving the familiar environment of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity screen (Guided Selling).

In this blog, I will explain some key aspects of the Quote integration from SAP Sales Cloud V2 to SAP CPQ, covering the key prerequisites and steps to set up the integration.

What This Integration Means to the end users:

Sales team can now leverage key features of sales quotation management directly from the SAP Sales Cloud V2 Guided Selling screen:

  • Direct Quote Creation from Opportunity object: Initiate an SAP CPQ quote directly from an existing opportunity in Sales Cloud V2. Customer and context data are transferred automatically, eliminating manual data entry and speeding up the sales cycle.
  • Seamless, Embedded CPQ Access: Launch the robust SAP CPQ quoting interface right from within Sales Cloud V2. With SSO enabled, you can access CPQ instantly without the need entering credentials.
  • Real-Time Data Consistency: Forget manual updates. Product quantities and final quote values are automatically synced back to the related Sales Cloud V2 opportunity in real-time, ensuring your pipeline data is always accurate and consistent.
  • Clean & Efficient API-Driven Architecture: Uses direct API communication between Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, with no shadow quote creation in Sales Cloud V2 — reducing redundancy and improving efficiency

Typical Use Case of CPQ Quotation from Sales Cloud V2

Initiating the Quote in Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity

The journey begins, naturally, in SAP Sales Cloud V2.

  • A user creates a new Opportunity, capturing essential details like customer information and sales context.
  • The user populates the Opportunity with initial Products and specifies the desired quantities. This sets the foundation for the quote.
  • To launch the formal quotation process, the user selects the External Sales Quote option.

This action instantly triggers the creation of a follow-up quote in SAP CPQ, powered by the standard content within SAP Cloud Integration.

Seamless Navigation and Pre-filled Data

Once the quote is generated in CPQ, the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity is immediately updated.

  • The newly created CPQ quote is visible directly within the Opportunity's Sales Quote section.
  • The user can seamlessly navigate to the full CPQ quoting interface by simply clicking the quotation hyperlink. This smooth transition is enabled by the External Link configuration in Sales Cloud V2.
  • Zero data entry is required for the initial quote. The CPQ quote screen is pre-filled with all the details pulled from the opportunity: products, quantities, and initial estimated prices.

Real-Time Synchronization and Data Consistency

As the quote matures in CPQ (pricing, configuration, discounting), the two systems remain perfectly synchronized:

  • Document Flow Update: The quote ID is instantly added to the Opportunity's Document Flow, providing a clear audit trail.
  • Real-Time Data Flush & Fill: As you update the quote in CPQ, a real-time synchronization pushes key data points—such as the quote status and discounts—back to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Instant Financial Updates: A quick refresh of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity instantly updates the Net Value and Negotiated Value, reflecting the latest changes made in CPQ.

Handling Complex Products: Configuring Quotes from Sales Cloud V2

While the standard workflow is great for simple product sets, what about complex, configurable products? The integration handles this seamlessly as well, keeping the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity as the starting point.

For products requiring detailed configuration (like machinery, specialized services, or complex bundles), the process adjusts slightly:

  • Skip the Opportunity Product Entry: You no longer need to add the product directly to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Launch CPQ for Configuration: Using the External Sales Quote option (as described previously), you initiate the quote in CPQ.
  • Configure and Save: Products are added and configured as required directly within the SAP CPQ interface.
  • Full Data Pushback: When you save the configured quote, the system ensures complete data transfer. The detailed configuration data—including the final products used, quantities, and calculated amounts—is then pushed back and added to the associated Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.

This capability ensures that whether the product is simple or highly complex, your Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity remains the accurate, single source of truth for the financial and product details of the deal.

Furthermore, if you want to embed the SAP CPQ screen directly in an Opportunity in Sales Cloud V2 using the Mashup Authoring extensibility feature.

 

Key Benefits of This Unified Approach

  • Seamlessly move from Opportunity to Quote and back, eliminating disruptive system-hopping for sales users.
  • Automated data transfer and real-time synchronization ensure consistent, accurate data between Sales Cloud V2 and CPQ, drastically reducing manual errors.
  • Leveraging prebuilt iFlows through SAP Cloud Integration minimizes custom development work, allowing you to deploy and realize benefits much faster.

 

Integration setup:

Before going through steps required to setup the integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, here are some prerequisites which you must meet:

  1. CPQ Requirement: Must use a CPQ tenant with the Quote 2.0 framework enabled.
  2. Integration Dependency: CPQ integration requires S/4HANA Integration to function (it is delivered for joint use).
  3. Master Data Setup: Complete the Initial Load of Master Data from S/4HANA to Sales Cloud V2, OR update all relevant Sales Cloud V2 External IDs with the S/4HANA System ID reference.
  4. ID Mapping Rule: ID mapping is indirect via S/4HANA. S/4HANA IDs are the primary reference between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2.
  5. Error Warning: Missing external IDs will trigger the error: "Outbound Synchronous request mapping failed."
  6. Configuration Constraint: The Opportunity to External Sales Quote configuration in Sales Cloud V2 must be unique (e.g., cannot configure for both CPQ and S/4HANA simultaneously). Multiple configurations result in the error: "Missing unique configuration for external quote communication."

Configurations required in SAP Sales Cloud:

  • Create Communication systems for S/4HANA & Cloud Integration (CPI connecting to CPQ) systems. Enable Inbound user & outbound communication for CPI system (configure the outbound https host as CPI runtime host).
  • Create a Communication Configuration by copying template “Integrate Opportunity with SAP CPQ”. Use the Cloud integration system name as comm. system.
  • In Properties comm configuration, set the S/4HANA system name
  • Add “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP S/4HANA, SAP ERP, or SAP CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to sync the quote data from CPQ to Sales V2. It will be trigger when you refresh the opportunity.
  • Add “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to update the follow up document details with CPQ quote.
  • Set the API path for Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity HTTP outbound with runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to trigger the CPQ quote creation from Sales Cloud V2 on click of External CPQ Quote submission.
  • In the inbound configuration, make sure the Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details is configured in the communication configuration. This inbound configuration will be used to update the Opportunity with CPQ status, amounts, discounts, etc data.
  • Configure External Link to navigate to SAP CPQ quote screen from Opportunity. For this, set the below:
    • External Object - Sales Quote
    • Communication system - CPI system name (created in step 1)
    • Link - https://<CPQDomain>.cpq.cloud.sap/fed/<federationName>/cart/edit?cartcompositenumber=${displayId}

Configurations required in SAP Cloud Integration:

  • Use the Cloud Integration standard package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ  to integrate sales quotes between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ.
  • Below are key interfaces to be configured:

Create Follow-up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity (to create the quote in CPQ)

Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ (to update the follow-up document with quote id from CPQ)

Retrieve Document Flow from CPQ (to update the opportunity with Quote ID, set primary quote)

Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details (to update opportunity with CPQ quote data like negotiation amount, discounts, etc when the quote is saved or submitted)

Additionally, if you are using subscription products in opportunity Sales Cloud V2, then use Update Subscription Product Fields in SAP CPQ Quote to sync the quote updates from CPQ to Sales Cloud.

  • Configure the Value Mapping with respective processing statuses, rejection statuses, owner names between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2 systems.

Configurations required in SAP CPQ:

  • Subscribe to Quote events to update the Sales Cloud opportunity with Quote data. You can use QuoteEvent (OnSaveAction) to trigger Cloud integration iflow Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details.
  • If directly login is required with SSO, enable SSO with federation settings between both Sales cloud v2 and CPQ to be setup using SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service in BTP.

References links:

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP CPQ Quote 2.0

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP Sales Cloud V2

Quote integration between SAP CPQ and Sales Cloud V2

Enable SSO in SAP CPQ

Enable SSO in Sales Cloud V2

entry.title: New fixes and features in the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package with the Dec 2025 shipment
entry.content:
We have just shipped new versions of the following Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages, this time rather smaller changes and also reacting on a customer ticket which is fixed now:

  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Inbound version 1.0.5
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Pipelines version 1.0.3
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Templates version 1.1.0

Please update the packages in your Design area to benefit from the changes.

For the generic outbound package, we haven't done any changes this time. Here, we have just recently shipped major changes with the two new generic integration flows for XI and IDoc outbound. See Generic XI Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline and Generic IDoc Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline.

The following new features have been shipped at a glance:

  • We have changed the duplicate handling for the generic XI and IDoc inbound processing flows as follows: In case of duplicates, the message processing logs end with Completed instead of Escalated to avoid that an http error code 500 is returned to the sending system.
  • For testing purposes, you can now switch off the duplicate check for the generic IDoc inbound processing flow. By default, the duplicate handling is enabled.
  • The XI inbound processing flow now supports dynamic adapter-specific headers. A feature which has just recently be shipped with an enhancement of the XI adapter. See Dynamic Headers.
  • An Exactly Once In Order (EOIO) check has been added to the IDoc inbound processing flow. Since we do not support EOIO in the Pipeline yet, the message goes into an error.
  • The definition of alternative partners has been extended to be able to determine partner ID based on sender component name, sender interface name, and sender interface namespace. This was supported before for XI and IDoc inbound scenarios, now you can do this for any scenario if required. If not, you can stick to the option to determine partner ID based on sender component name and sender interface name only.
  • We fixed an issue with a wrong reference to a script in the Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Sync flow.
  • The allowed headers list of the template flow Pipeline v2 Template - Custom Exit has been extended to support the header SapQualityOfService. This way, you have the option to use or change the SapQualityOfService header in a custom pre-processing flow. For instance, you do not like to change the EOIO setup of an XI interface in the sender system but still like to process the messages in the Pipeline accepting EO delivery as long as the Pipeline doesn't support EOIO. So you can call the custom exit flow right at the beginning of the generic XI inbound flow and switch from ExactlyOnceInOrder to ExactlyOnce.
  • A new template Pipeline v2 Template Step07 - Outbound Processing Point-to-Point to Generic XI Outbound has been added that allows you to create a scenario-specific outbound processing flow that calls the generic XI outbound processing flow. The template can be used for both synchronous and asynchronous communication.
  • A new template Pipeline v2 Template Step07 - Outbound Processing Point-to-Point to Generic IDoc Outbound has been added that allows you to create a scenario-specific outbound processing flow that calls the generic IDoc outbound processing flow.

Here some of the new features in more detail.

Duplicate handling

As said, we have changed the duplicate handling for the generic XI and IDoc inbound processing flows. Before, if a duplicate message was sent to the flows, the duplicate message ended with status Escalated and hence an http error code 500 was returned to the sender system. The issue was that then the sender kept restarting and resending the duplicate message. To overcome this issue, the duplicate message now ends with Completed. In addition, the custom status shows that the duplicate has been discarded.

Furthermore, for testing purposes in your test environment, you can now send duplicate IDoc messages by switching off the duplicate check. This can be done by configuring the generic IDoc inbound flow. In this case, you need to change the configuration parameter CustomXTest_SkipDuplicateCheck to true. By default, the value is false.

If you now resend the very same IDoc, it will be processed. In addition, the custom status shows that the duplicate check has been skipped.

New templates

In order to call the generic XI and IDoc outbound processing flows, you need to create a scenario-specific outbound flow. You can now create such flows as copy of the new templates Pipeline v2 Template Step07 - Outbound Processing Point-to-Point to Generic XI Outbound and Pipeline v2 Template Step07 - Outbound Processing Point-to-Point to Generic IDoc Outbound, respectively. By using the templates instead of creating the flows from scratch or using the other templates for outbound processing, you ensure that all settings such as the allowed headers or the ProcessDirect connection to the generic outbound flows have been properly set.

The template for the XI outbound can be used for both synchronous and asynchronous communication. Especially for synchronous calls, it is important to use this dedicated template and not the Pipeline v2 Template Step07 - Outbound Processing Synchronous template. Latter removes some internally used headers before calling the request reply step because here we would call an external service. For calling the generix XI outbound flow however, we need to keep the headers because they should be passed to the generic XI outbound flow. In addition, the XI headers of the response like SapRefToMessageId are fetched and added to the custom header properties so that they are displayed in the message processing logs.

Dynamic headers

The XI adapter supports dynamic adapter-specific headers, see Dynamic Headers. This feature is now leveraged in the generic XI inbound processing flow. If the sender sends dynamic configurations in the XI header, the XI sender adapter converts them into a pair of exchange properties with prefix SapDynamicConfiguration: one exchange property for the parameter name and value and one for its namespace. In order to pass the dynamic configurations to the pipeline steps, the generic XI inbound processing flow creates corresponding headers with prefix dc_SapDynamicConfiguration. For this, there was no need to change the generic pipeline steps or the templates, all headers starting with the prefix dc were already in the allowed headers list. You can then use the configurations in the pipeline steps or the scenario-specific flows, e.g, you can use them in an Xpath in the XSLT to determine your receivers in a content-based-router pattern. In the screenshot below, I have switched on the trace for the integrated messaging runtime flow from where you can see the dynamic configurations.

For the generic XI outbound flow, those dynamic headers are not supported yet. In our next increment of the pipeline packages, we plan to enhance the generic XI outbound flow so that those headers are automatically converted into corresponding properties. The XI receiver adapter checks for those properties and adds them to the outgoing XI message. Furthermore, we look into enhancing the pipeline to better support IDocs with partner type other than LS such as LI or KU. We plan to ship this in the next increment. So stay tuned.

entry.title: End-to-End Message Tracking and Retry Control in SAP Cloud integration
entry.content:
In this post, we’ll explore an end-to-end asynchronous scenario where the sender is XI (Proxy) and the receiver is an API. The goal is to avoid infinite JMS retries, persist messages in JMS queues, and track them effectively in SAP Cloud Integration (CI) monitoring.

 

Scenario Overview

For message processing from the S/4HANA sender system, we use a common artifact that:

  • Determines whether the message is sync or async (via a Sync Call Router).
  • For async messages, routes them into a common JMS queue.
  • For sync messages, dynamically identifies the preceding iFlow based on sender interface and namespace.

 

 

 

The next iFlow:

  • Reads messages from the common JMS queue.
  • Dynamically determines the preceding iFlow using Sender Interface Name and Namespace.

 

Retry Configuration

In my case, maximum retries are set to 6. Here’s how it works:

 

  1. Message delivered on first attempt
    → No retry triggered; message reaches the end system successfully.
  2. Message fails but succeeds within retry limit (e.g., 4th attempt)
    → Each retry invokes the exception subprocess, which calls the local integration process (max retry condition) until the threshold is reached.

 

  1. Maximum retry condition reached
    → Message is routed to the exception subprocess, then moved to a quarantine queue.
    → An email notification is sent to stakeholders for further action.

 

 

The Catch: Tracking and Reprocessing Messages

While many posts cover retries and exception handling, the key challenge is tracking a specific message and moving it back to the original queue for reprocessing (a feature introduced in Q3 2025).

 

For XI messages:

  • Retrieve SAP Message ID from SXMB_MONI.

 

  • Add it to CI Camel header values (SAP_ApplicationID).

 

Useful Identifiers

  • ${SapMessageId} → XI Adapter Message ID (uppercase, no dashes)
  • ${SapMessageIdEx} → XI Adapter Message ID (lowercase, with dashes)
  • ${header.SAP_DataStoreRetries} → Retry count for DataStore
  • ${header.SAPJMSRetries} → Retry count for JMS

 

Steps to Reprocess

  1. Identify the last retried message using Correlation ID in CI Monitoring.

 

  1. Locate the message in the quarantine queue using the Message ID from the message and search the same in your quarantine queue

 

 

The message identified in quarantine queue.

 

  1. After stakeholder deliberation:
    • Move the message back to the original queue for reprocessing.
    • Delete if no longer needed.
    • Or retain in quarantine (monitor JMS resources to avoid exhaustion).

 

Summary

  • We explained how to restrict retries in CI to prevent endless JMS loops and also avoid storage exhaustion.
  • We also covered tracking messages that hit retry limits and taking subsequent actions (move, delete, or retain).

entry.title: OData V4 API Pagination in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

INTRODUCTION:

In this blog post, I will explain how you can implement client-side pagination for an OData V4 API in SAP CPI (Cloud Platform Integration). Pagination is essential when dealing with large datasets, as it helps control the amount of data transferred and processed in each request.

In this scenario, I have used the Product Master OData V4 API  to demonstrate client-side pagination.

Why Client-Side Pagination?

While automatic server-side pagination in the SAP CPI OData adapter works well for smaller datasets, it may introduce additional latency when processing very large volumes of data due to multiple sequential service calls.

To better control performance and batch size, client-side pagination was explicitly managed in SAP CPI by using OData query options such as $top and $skip. This allows CPI to request data in controlled chunks, optimize payload size, and better manage processing and memory utilization, while the actual pagination is still performed on the OData server.

Let’s start implementing in SAP CPI:

Create in IFLOW in SAP CI Tenant as below: 

Main Integration I-Flow

1: Use a Timer:

For the purpose of this blog, a Timer is used to trigger the iFlow.

2: Create Exchange Properties in Content Modifier:

Below Properties are created:

  • top = 5000 → Number of records to fetch per page (max value can be 5000 per page)
  • skip = 0 → Initial offset for fetching records

3: Looping Process Call

A Looping Process Call will repeatedly call the LIP (Local Integration Process).
The loop condition is:  ${property.emptyPayload} = 'false'

Local Integration Process:

i : OData V4 adapter with Request-Reply

Below query Parameters are used:
$select=Product,CreationDate,LastChangeDate&$top=${property.top}&$skip=${property.skip}

  • $select →  to retrieve specific field
  • $top → Number of records per call
  • $skip → Offset for fetching records

This ensures only the required fields are fetched in each batch.



ii: Groovy Script to Handle Pagination
Groovy script is used to manage the pagination logic. Its purpose is to:

  1. Check if the payload is empty:
    • If the API returns no records, it sets emptyPayload = true to stop the loop.
    • Otherwise, it keeps emptyPayload = false to continue fetching the next batch.
  2. Increment the skip property:
    • Retrieves the current skip value
    • Adds the page size (e.g., 5000) to it for the next iteration.

Remove First and Last Line: That carries the root node tags.
Groovy Script:

import com.sap.it.script.v2.api.Message
import java.io.Reader

Message processData(Message message) {
Reader reader = message.getBody(Reader)
String body = reader.text
def lines = body.readLines()
if (lines.size() > 0) lines.remove(0)
if (lines.size() > 0) lines.remove(lines.size() - 1)
body = lines.join("\n")
message.setBody(body)
def skipValue = message.getProperty("skip") as String
int skip = skipValue ? skipValue.toInteger() : 0
skip += 5000
message.setProperty("skip", skip)
message.setProperty("emptyPayload", body.trim() ? "false" : "true")
return message
}

 Below are the screenshots to depict how the above groovy will execute:

CamelLoopIndex is increasing as per available no of pages to check if data is available in each page. Basis on data availability a custom property- emptyPayload  set as true or false. 

Now you can see the increment in skip value and top remain unchanged.

iii: Append Payload in Each Iteration

 Content Modifier is used to gather the payload for each iteration. Below Exchange property is created:
storepayload = ${property.storepayload}${in.body}

In Message Body of Content Modifier:
${property.storepayload}

Step i, ii, iii in LIP will execute in loop until condition ${property.emptyPayload} = ‘false’ is met.

Local Integration Process will stop calling when condition is not met in looping process call, The loop will end here.
(Back to main integration process)

4: Add root node.
Content Modifier wraps the gathered payload under a single root node:

Voilà! The process ends here!!!!!

Conclusion: 

Client-side pagination provides full control over page size by allowing the use of $top and $skip as needed, whereas server-side pagination can result in unpredictable page sizes.
I would recommend using OData Adapter for OData v2/v4 APIs over HTTP adapter because for any error, reason can be traced throw OData response body/headers that provides more realistic understanding of reason of failure. 

I hope this blog post proves useful for implementing client-side pagination for an OData V4 API.

Thanks for reading!

entry.title: Getting Unconventional with Groovy - Part 2 - connecting to SAP CI's underlying postgree DB
entry.content:
Introduction:

Before I start this let me share that this article is just for the curious bunch of people. I am not recommending you to connect to postgree db of SAP CI for any productive scenarios.

SAP CI exposes the following credentials / private keys in System Env variable VCAP_SERVICES

Security Credentials Exposed in VCAP_SERVICES

Exposed Credentials and Keys

Database Credentials (PostgreSQL)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Plain text username and password
  • Full database connection strings with hostname, port, dbname
  • SSL certificates (root CA certificates)
  • Direct access to production database with full CRUD permissions

Certificate-Based Authentication (Multiple Services)

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • X.509 client certificates (full certificate chains)
  • Private RSA keys (PKCS#8 and PEM formats) for:
    • Connectivity service
    • Enterprise messaging
    • Destination service
    • XSUAA (authentication)
    • Kafka
  • These private keys provide identity proof and decrypt capabilities

OAuth2 / XSUAA Tokens

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client IDs and client secrets
  • Token endpoints and verification keys
  • Service instance IDs
  • Tenant/zone identifiers

Kafka Credentials

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Username and password for Kafka authentication
  • Client certificates and private keys
  • Broker endpoints (hostnames and ports)
  • Topic-level permissions mapping

Credential Store Encryption Keys

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • Client private keys for encryption
  • Server public keys
  • OAuth credentials for accessing the credential store itself
  • Access policy definitions showing what namespaces can be accessed

Azure Blob Storage

  • Risk Level: HIGH
  • Storage account names
  • SAS (Shared Access Signature) tokens with full container access
  • Container URIs and region information

Dynatrace APM

  • Risk Level: MEDIUM
  • API tokens with environment access
  • Environment IDs
  • API URLs

Connectivity Service

  • Risk Level: CRITICAL
  • On-premise proxy hostnames and ports
  • Certificates and private keys
  • Access to Cloud Connector for hybrid connectivity

As I have maintained this is a security risk and SAP should plug this. Username and Passwords SHOULD NOT be available/visible at all in VCAP_SERVICES file.

anyways..here is a groovy script that finds out all the tables on the postgree sql db, lists them and also lists top 10 rows from each table. 

This is only a read operation and does not modify the db in any way.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            psql_hostname + ":" + psql_port, 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def tables = []
        
        // If body is empty, get all tables first
        if (body == null || body.trim().isEmpty()) {
            def tableQuery = """
                SELECT table_name 
                FROM information_schema.tables 
                WHERE table_schema = 'public' 
                AND table_type = 'BASE TABLE'
                ORDER BY table_name
            """
            def tableResults = sql.rows(tableQuery)
            tables = tableResults.collect { it.table_name }
        } else {
            // Parse JSON array from body
            def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
            def parsed = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
            
            if (parsed instanceof List) {
                parsed.each { item ->
                    if (item instanceof String) {
                        tables.add(item)
                    } else if (item instanceof Map && item.table_name) {
                        tables.add(item.table_name)
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        output.append("{\n")
        output.append("  \"_meta\": {\"tables_scanned\": ${tables.size()}, \"timestamp\": \"${new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')}\"},\n")
        
        tables.eachWithIndex { tableName, tableIdx ->
            output.append("  \"${tableName}\": {\n")
            
            try {
                // Get row count
                def countResult = sql.firstRow("SELECT COUNT(*) as cnt FROM \"${tableName}\"".toString())
                def rowCount = countResult?.cnt ?: 0
                output.append("    \"total_rows\": ${rowCount},\n")
                
                // Get columns with types
                def colQuery = """
                    SELECT column_name, data_type 
                    FROM information_schema.columns 
                    WHERE table_name = '${tableName}' 
                    ORDER BY ordinal_position
                """.toString()
                def columns = sql.rows(colQuery)
                output.append("    \"columns\": [")
                output.append(columns.collect { "\"${it.column_name}(${it.data_type})\"" }.join(", "))
                output.append("],\n")
                
                // Get top 10 rows
                def rows = sql.rows("SELECT * FROM \"${tableName}\" LIMIT 10".toString())
                output.append("    \"data\": [\n")
                
                rows.eachWithIndex { row, rowIdx ->
                    output.append("      {")
                    def cols = []
                    row.each { key, value ->
                        def valStr = sanitizeValue(value)
                        cols.add("\"${key}\": \"${valStr}\"")
                    }
                    output.append(cols.join(", "))
                    output.append("}")
                    if (rowIdx < rows.size() - 1) output.append(",")
                    output.append("\n")
                }
                
                output.append("    ]\n")
                
            } catch (Exception e) {
                output.append("    \"error\": \"${e.message.replaceAll('"', "'").take(200)}\"\n")
            }
            
            output.append("  }")
            if (tableIdx < tables.size() - 1) output.append(",")
            output.append("\n")
        }
        
        output.append("}")
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

def String sanitizeValue(Object value) {
    if (value == null) return "null"
    
    def str = value.toString()
    
    // Handle binary/byte arrays
    if (value instanceof byte[]) {
        str = "[BINARY: ${value.length} bytes]"
    }
    
    // Truncate, escape quotes and newlines
    str = str.take(500)
        .replaceAll('\\\\', '\\\\\\\\')
        .replaceAll('"', '\\\\"')
        .replaceAll('\n', '\\\\n')
        .replaceAll('\r', '\\\\r')
        .replaceAll('\t', '\\\\t')
    
    return str
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

 

But lets not stop here. SAP must have given these creds in plaintext for a reason and maybe we should go ahead and create a table of our own and insert some values as well.

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.sql.Sql;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String);
    DatabaseManager db = null
    
    try {
        def vcapJson = java.lang.System.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES")
        def vcap = new JsonSlurper().parseText(vcapJson)
        def psql = vcap."postgresql-db"[0].credentials
        
        def psql_username = psql.username
        def psql_password = psql.password
        def psql_hostname = psql.hostname
        def psql_port = psql.port
        def psql_dbname = psql.dbname
        
        db = new DatabaseManager(
            "${psql_hostname}:${psql_port}", 
            psql_dbname, 
            psql_username, 
            psql_password
        )
        
        Sql sql = db.getSql();
        def output = new StringBuilder()
        
        // Create table
        output.append("=== Creating Table ===\n")
        sql.execute('''
            CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS test_table (
                id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
                name VARCHAR(100),
                created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
            )
        '''.toString())
        output.append("Table 'test_table' created successfully\n\n")
        
        // Insert row
        output.append("=== Inserting Row ===\n")
        def timestamp = new Date().format('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
        def insertSQL = 'INSERT INTO test_table (name) VALUES (?) RETURNING id, name, created_at'
        def insertedRow = sql.firstRow(insertSQL, ["Test Entry ${timestamp}".toString()])
        output.append("Inserted row: ID=${insertedRow.id}, Name=${insertedRow.name}, Created=${insertedRow.created_at}\n\n")
        
        // Select and display results
        output.append("=== Selecting All Rows ===\n")
        def selectSQL = 'SELECT * FROM test_table ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 10'
        def rows = sql.rows(selectSQL)
        
        output.append("Found ${rows.size()} row(s):\n")
        rows.each { row ->
            output.append("  ID: ${row.id} | Name: ${row.name} | Created: ${row.created_at}\n")
        }
        
        message.setBody(output.toString())
        
    } catch (Exception e) {
        message.setBody("ERROR: ${e.message}\n\nStack: ${e.stackTrace.take(10).join('\n')}")
    } finally {
        if (db != null) {
            db.close()
        }
    }
    
    return message;
}

class DatabaseManager {
    private Sql sql
    private boolean isConnected = false
    
    DatabaseManager(String hostPort, String database, String username, String password) {
        String jdbcUrl = "jdbc:postgresql://${hostPort}/${database}?sslmode=require"
        try {
            this.sql = Sql.newInstance(jdbcUrl, username, password, "org.postgresql.Driver")
            this.isConnected = true
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new RuntimeException("Failed to connect to database: ${e.message}", e)
        }
    }
    
    Sql getSql() {
        if (!isConnected) {
            throw new IllegalStateException("Database connection is closed")
        }
        return sql
    }
    
    void close() {
        if (sql != null && isConnected) {
            sql.close()
            isConnected = false
        }
    }
}

Result

=== Creating Table ===
Table 'test_table' created successfully

=== Inserting Row ===
Inserted row: ID=3, Name=Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04, Created=2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478

=== Selecting All Rows ===
Found 3 row(s):
  ID: 3 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:04 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:04.248478
  ID: 2 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:52:02 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:52:02.147281
  ID: 1 | Name: Test Entry 2025-12-24 04:51:55 | Created: 2025-12-24 04:51:55.597395

 

This script will perhaps help SAP CI developers understand how certain things work in SAP CI at the database level.

Again I am not encouraging anyone to modify the postgree db of SAP CI and this is only here for the curious bunch.

entry.title: A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
entry.content:
A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
CPI also creates context changes automatically when parallel queues advance differently.

What is really happening in your case

You have THREE relevant queues aligned in mapping:

  1. productTaxItem

  2. some other node (likely RECORDTYPE / TaxCode / something parallel)

  3. companyCodeOut (your UDF output)

Your UDF only controls companyCodeOut,
but CPI aligns all queues together.

Notice:

  • companyCodeOut value is SAME (BB01)

  • But another queue changes context (B2 → 22)

CPI inserts an implicit context change to stay aligned with the other node.

So:

  • Context 2 → created by your UDF

  • Context 3 → created automatically by CPI due to parallel node context shift

That’s why they appear together.
